 Legislature rejects proposed amendment banning gay marriage
 By Associated Press
 Wednesday, September 14, 2005 - Updated: 04:01 PM EST
 
 BOSTON - A year after the nation's first state-sanctioned same-sex marriages began taking place, the Massachusetts Legislature on Wednesday rejected a proposed constitutional amendment that sought to ban gay marriage but legalize civil unions. 
 
 After less than two hours of debate, a joint session of the House and Senate voted 157-39 against the measure.

 I too think abortion and gay rights to be very seperate issues. In my opinion, there are a lot of good reasons to disallow abortion, and there are a lot of good reasons to allow abortion. This is the case in most debates. However, in the case of gay rights, I don't believe that there is even a single logical reason to oppose giving gay people the same access to marriage that we give straight people.
 
 In the case of abortion, it could be argued that human lives are being saved. That, if correct, is a good reason; if that's correct, then abortion causes incredible harm; it kills. It's difficult to say where the line between human and reproductive material should be drawn, but there are good arguments on both sides.
 
 In the case of same-sex marriage, the arguments against it are, "We'd have to redefine a word" (though redefining a word isn't harmful in any way) or "I just don't believe homosexuality is moral" (which is advocating imposing one's own religion into the law when no real harm exists) or "homosexuality is harmful" (which isn't true) or "gay parents aren't the ideal parents" (which is neither true, nor does it matter since they're unquestionably better than no parents) or some argument based on prejudices of some sort. Those are not rational arguments.
 
 And furthermore, same-sex marriage is certainly guaranteed by the Constitution while the right to an abortion is, in my opinion, not clearly present in the Constitution.
